description: From Middle English pippe, from Middle Dutch pip, from post-classical Latin pipita, from Latin pītuīta (“mucus, phlegm, head cold”). Doublet of pituita.

entries.meaning: Any of various respiratory diseases in birds, especially infectious coryza. [from the 15th c.]
(humorous, dated) Of humans, a disease, malaise or depression.
examples: I've got the pip horribly at present.

description: Apparently representing a shortened form of pippin, from Middle English pipin, from Old French pepin (“a seed”) (French pépin).

definitionGroups.group: (obsolete) A pippin, seed of any kind.

entries.meaning: (UK) A seed inside certain fleshy fruits (compare stone/pit), such as a peach, orange, or apple.
examples: Apple pips are edible, but don't have a pleasant taste.

entries.meaning: (US, colloquial) Something or someone excellent, of high quality.
examples: She sure is a pip, that one. You need company?

entries.meaning: (Britain, dated, World War I, signalese) P in RAF phonetic alphabet.

verbs.description: pip (third-person singular simple present pips, present participle pipping, simple past and past participle pipped)

description: Origin uncertain; perhaps related to Etymology 2, above.

entries.meaning: One of the spots or symbols on a playing card, domino, die, etc.
(military, public service) One of the stylised version of the Bath star worn on the shoulder of a uniform to denote rank, e.g. of a soldier or a fireman.
A spot of light or an inverted V indicative of a return of radar waves reflected from an object; a blip.
A piece of rhizome with a dormant shoot of the lily of the valley plant, used for propagation

verbs.description: pip (third-person singular simple present pips, present participle pipping, simple past and past participle pipped)

entries.meaning: To get the better of; to defeat by a narrow margin
examples: He led throughout the race but was pipped at the post.
The hunter managed to pip three ducks from his blind.

verbs.description: pip (third-person singular simple present pips, present participle pipping, simple past and past participle pipped)

entries.meaning: (avian biology) To make the initial hole during the process of hatching from an egg

One of a series of very short, electronically produced tones, used, for example, to count down the final few seconds before a given time or to indicate that a caller using a payphone needs to make further payment to continue the call.
examples: I could clearly hear the frequent cataclysms of the upstairs lavatory, and my day began with the pips for the morning news in Charlotte Lawless's kitchen.

entries.meaning: (finance, currency trading) The smallest price increment between two currencies in foreign exchange (forex) trading.
